posts._title: Yasujirô Ozu – Higanbana AKA Equinox Flower (1958)
posts.title: Higanbana
posts.excerpt: Quote: The first color feature film from Yasujiro Ozu, Equinox Flower is a spare, evocative, and compassionate portrait of aging, transition, and change. The title of the film refers to a red amaryllis flower that blooms near the autumnal equinox, and red imagery pervade the film: the brick train station building, the carpeting of the …

posts.title: Ordet
posts.excerpt: Quote: Although The Word deals with a miracle, it is through and through a realistic film—about those who are weak in faith. The hoped-for miracle does not occur until one who has faith, the True Faith, arrives. The action takes place among country folk living in a small, outlying parish on Jutland’s west coast. It …

posts._title: Manoel de Oliveira – O Pão AKA Bread [Short Version] (1959)
posts.title: O Pão
posts.excerpt: Quote: Each day, a man must work around the clock to produce and acquire bread: throwing the seeds into earth, helping the breeding of the corn, the corn’s recolt, transport to the mills, manipulation of the flour into actual bread, transport to a variety of locations and consumers.

posts._title: Chan-wook Park – Ah-ga-ssi AKA The Handmaiden (2016)
posts.title: Ah-ga-ssi
posts.excerpt: Quote: Park Chan-wook’s giddy mixture of historical romance and auteur eroticism is spiced with ghosts, horror and S&M. Expectations are fully met in Park Chan-wook’s exquisitely filmed The Handmaiden (Agassi), an amusingly kinky erotic thriller and love story that brims with delicious surprises, making its two-and-a-half hours fly by. Though spiced up with nudity and …

posts.title: Shadow World
posts.excerpt: Based on the book of The Shadow World, this feature length documentary is an investigation into the multi-billion dollar international arms trade.

posts.title: Friday Mosque
posts.excerpt: A silent meditation on the Islamic prayer ritual through motion (water is the core, but light is the cause) in FRIDAY MOSQUE. Shot on high-contrast black and white 16mm film, Navai hand processed the negative and painstakingly contact- printed the strips of celluloid. The resulting image quivers and pulses. Enlarged film grain nearly obliterates the …

posts._title: Aleksandr Rou – Vechera na khutore bliz Dikanki AKA The Night Before Christmas (1961)
posts.title: Vechera na khutore bliz Dikanki
posts.excerpt: The whimsical combination of Christmas phantasmagoria and an eccentric fairy tale makes this film an unforgettable spectacle. The action takes place both in a village of Dikanka in the Ukraine and at the palace of a Russian Empress. Blacksmith Vacula has enraged the devil himself: in a church he painted the devil’s figure in such …

posts._title: Robert Fischer & Wilfried Reichart – The Mysteries of Paris: Jacques Rivette’s Out 1 Revisited (2015)
posts.title: The Mysteries of Paris: Jacques Rivette’s Out 1 Revisited
posts.excerpt: Quote: There’s little doubt that, for the serious cinephile, the home video event of this fall will be the the release of Jacques Rivette’s magnum opus OUT 1 (1971) on blu-ray and DVD in three territories: Carlotta Films and Carlotta US will kick off on November 18 in France and the USA respectively, with Arrow …

posts.title: Europe, She Loves
posts.excerpt: official site wrote: Four couples struggle on the edge of mother Europe. In countries troubled by economic and social crises they stumble through life with charme, sex and plenty of passion. A movie about the politics of love. In Sevilla JUAN, 21, and CARO, 23, experience the wonder of a young love. However, Juan is …

posts.title: Homo sapiens
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: Homo Sapiens is a film about the finiteness and fragility of human existence and the end of the industrial age, and what it means to be a human being. What will remain of our lives after we’re gone? Empty spaces, ruins, cities increasingly overgrown with vegetation, crumbling asphalt: the areas we currently inhabit, though …
